The order was reserved by the high court on February 28.In this case, the Enforcement Directorate is probing the alleged "huge amounts of proceeds of crime generated by manipulation of official records by showing dummy sellers and purchasers in the guise of forged/bogus documents to acquire huge parcels of land having value in crores'.Soren, in his plea filed through advocate Pragya Baghel, had said there has been a pattern that has emerged and it is reflected in the actions of the ED for prosecuting and targeting individuals, especially political leaders belonging to the opposition, on the basis of "cooked-up allegations"."Knowing that the elections are around the corner and with a malafide intent of paralysing the leaders of opposition political parties, of which Hemant Soren being the leader of the Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM) was arrested on January 31, 2024," his plea said.Soren was arrested on January 31 in the case after he resigned as Jharkhand chief minister, and party loyalist and state transport minister Champai Soren was named as his successor.
Article Summary: Soren had also sought interim bail for campaigning in the Lok Sabha elections till the high court delivers its verdict on his plea against arrest. Soren was arrested on January 31 in the case after he resigned as Jharkhand chief minister. The Enforcement Directorate is probing the alleged "huge amounts of proceeds of crime"

Article Title: Will quit politics if CM doesn't return to power, says Pandian; dares Pradhan to do so if BJP loses
Article Text: JHARSUGUDA: BJD leader V K Pandian on Friday said he would quit politics if chief minister Naveen Patnaik doesn't return to power with a three-fourth majority and dared Union minister Dharmendra Pradhan to do the same if BJP loses the elections in Odisha."I will retire from politics if Naveen Patnaik doesn't become the CM of Odisha again. Can the Union minister make a similar announcement if the BJP loses?" Pandian asked at a public gathering at Panchgaon Bazar ground in Lakhanpur block of Brajarajnagar assembly constituency.He was campaigning for BJD's Bargarh Lok Sabha candidate Parinita Mishra as well as assembly nominees Dipali Das (Jharsuguda) and Alaka Mohanty (Brajrajnagar).Slamming Dharmendra, Pandian said the Union minister has been disrespecting the CM. "You are coming here and saying that you have worked for the soil, but till now you haven't been able to fix the national highway, because of which thousands of people have died in accidents. So, where did you get the courage to disrespect our CM from?" he asked.Countering Pandian, BJP's candidate for Sambalpur assembly seat, Jayanarayan Mishra, said, "Such arrogance in democracy shows Pandian's political immaturity." He said that BJD ideologue Biju babu had lost from four Vidhan Sabha and one Lok Sabha seats in 1971. "One should respect people's mandate," Mishra said.Jharsuguda BJP candidate Tankadhar Tripathy said a person belonging to Tamil Naidu is talking about Odia 'swabhiman'. "He should keep in mind that Odisha is the first state which was formed on the basis of language. He will get an answer on June 4 itself," Tripathy said.
Article Summary: BJD leader V K Pandian said he would quit politics if chief minister Naveen Patnaik doesn't return to power with a three-fourth majority. Pandian dared Union minister Dharmendra Pradhan to do the same if BJP loses the elections in Odisha.

Article Title: BJP man in sting in HC for protection
Article Text: Gangadhar Koyal, BJP’s Sandeshkhali area chief who claimed in a sting video that many charges of rape and harassment were levelled against TMC at the behest of Bengal BJP seniors, moved Calcutta HC Friday along with his son seeking protection and quashing an FIR against them. The duo told HC they had informed CBI about the tension in the area triggered by the video and had pleaded for security.Justice Jay Sengupta asked how CBI could accept the duo’s complaint on its own when all Sandeshkhali matters were before the HC. The judge, however, allowed the Koyals’ petition.
Article Summary: Gangadhar Koyal, BJP’s Sandeshkhali area chief, moved Calcutta HC Friday along with his son seeking protection and quashing an FIR against them. The duo told HC they had informed CBI about the tension in the area triggered by the video and had pleaded for security.

Article Title: Haryana political game: Power dynamics, alliance shifts, and the fate of Nayab Saini govt
Article Text:
The power game

What about the numbers

Letters to governor

A 'confident' Nayab Saini

Experts' opinion and role of governor

NEW DELHI: The Haryana government , led by Nayab Singh Saini, has been thrown into turmoil after three independent MLAs withdrew their support. This development comes just two months after the BJP ended its alliance with the Jannayak Janata Party (JJP), led by Dushyant Chautala. The BJP also replaced its chief minister, with Saini taking over from Manohar Lal Khattar, as the party faces challenges in the ongoing Lok Sabha polls.The Congress, which gave the BJP a tough fight in the 2019 assembly polls by winning 31 seats compared to the BJP's 40, has gained fresh momentum following the independents' threat to bring down the Nayab Saini government.Although JJP leader Dushyant Chautala claims to have 10 MLAs, six of them have already indicated their separation from Dushyant's party. Even Dushyant may be unaware about the loyalty of his MLAs during a potential floor test. Two of them openly supported BJP candidates in the Lok Sabha polls, while at least three reportedly met Khattar and they might support the current state government."The opposition is doing vague calculations. During the floor test, if they can retain even 23 of their MLAs, it will be a big deal. I don't see any no-confidence motion being moved anytime soon, but if any such situation arises, we will have a floor test... Many JJP MLAs have given support to BJP. This is what I'm saying, they need to think beyond what meets the eye," said Khattar, while talking to news agency ANI.The Haryana assembly, which has 90 members, currently has a strength of 88 after an independent MLA, and former CM Khattar resigned to contest the Lok Sabha election from Karnal. The BJP has 40 MLAs, Congress 30, JJP 10, INLD 1, Gopal Kanda's Haryana Lokhit Party (HLP) 1, and 7 independents. With only 43 MLAs supporting the Nayab Saini government, it has clearly become a minority.Both the Congress and JJP have sought the governor's intervention. Bhupinder Singh Hooda, the leader of the opposition, has requested a meeting with the governor to present a memorandum regarding the current political situation and has called for the imposition of President's Rule . Dushyant Chautala, in his letter, stated that his party does not support the current government and is open to backing any other political party to form a new government. He demanded a floor test to determine the majority of the incumbent government.INLD leader Abhay Chautala demanded imposition of the President’s Rule in the state in case BJP fails to prove its majority in the House.Despite the challenges, Haryana CM Nayab Saini remains confident, citing the vote of confidence he received a month ago. He questioned Dushyant's timing and dismissed his concerns as election-related stress.The current BJP govt seems secure for the time being. As per established rules, a no-confidence motion against a government cannot be initiated within a six-month period following the previous one. The BJP government in Haryana had already faced a no-trust motion in February, making it ineligible for another such challenge at present.However, legislative experts have said that there is no codified rule preventing the introduction of a motion for a floor test in the House. In the current situation, the governor's role becomes crucial, as he can decide on convening the House for the floor test. The Constitution grants the governor the authority to summon, prorogue, and dissolve the state legislative assembly, and the Supreme Court has emphasized the governor's constitutional obligation to act judiciously and impartially in such matters.Haryana governor Bandaru Dattatreya, a native of Andhra Pradesh, was an RSS pracharak until 1989 before joining the BJP. He has served as a Union minister in both the Vajpayee and Modi governments and has been an MP for four terms. In 2019, he was appointed as the governor of Himachal Pradesh and later shifted to Haryana in 2021.The state is scheduled to go to assembly elections in October this year.
Article Summary: Haryana governor Bandaru Dattatreya was an RSS pracharak until 1989. He has served as an MP in both the Vajpayee and Modi governments. The Congress, which gave the BJP a tough fight in the 2019 assembly polls by winning 31 seats compared to the BJP's 40.

Article Title: Lok Sabha elections: Arvind Kejriwal hits trail running with roadshow today
Article Text: NEW DELHI: The campaign of Aam Aadmi Party and INDIA bloc for Lok Sabha elections in Delhi and other states has got a shot in the arm with Arvind Kejriwal set to join it from Saturday.Given interim bail by Supreme Court solely for the purpose of elections, the Delhi chief minister is losing no time in hitting the campaign trail. He will participate in a roadshow in south Delhi on Saturday along with his Punjab counterpart, Bhagwant Mann.Kejriwal draws big crowds to his public events and will be the star campaigner for his party. In his absence, the party’s Delhi state convener, Gopal Rai, and his cabinet colleagues, Saurabh Bharadwaj and Atishi, had stepped in. His wife Sunita’s roadshows were drawing crowds but couldn’t compare with Kejriwal’s chemistry with audiences.An important constituent of INDIA alliance , AAP has fielded 22 candidates in five states. The party is contesting on four seats in Delhi as part of a seat-sharing arrangement with Congress and on two each in Gujarat and Assam and one in Haryana. It has gone solo in Punjab and is contesting all 13 seats.While voting in Assam and Gujarat is over, Delhi and Chandigarh will go to polls on May 25 and Punjab on June 1. A senior party functionary said Kejriwal is likely to spend most of his time campaigning till May 23 – the last day of campaigning for the sixth phase of elections on May 25 – and will also go to Kurukshetra in Haryana. Since Punjab will go to polls in the seventh phase on June 1, the AAP chief may address rallies and participate in roadshows there after May 23.“To show solidarity with the INDIA bloc, Kejriwal may intermittently go to other states where the alliance partners are giving a tough fight to BJP and campaign for them,” said the party functionary. “We will soon draw up a plan for his campaign after speaking to other alliance partners and keeping their requirements in mind. The leaders of other parties would surely like to come to Delhi and campaign for AAP and Congress here.”The party is also likely to coin a new name for the campaign. After Kejriwal’s release on interim bail, AAP functionaries started using “Modi can’t stop Kejriwal” as a catchphrase.Another AAP functionary said Kejriwal coming out of jail will prove to be a “gamechanger” for the INDIA group. He claimed the Delhi CM is much in demand in other states as well and his joining the alliance partners will bolster their campaign.Minutes after the SC order, West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee said in a post on X said it will be “very helpful” in the context of the Lok Sabha polls. NCP (SP) chief Sharad Pawar welcomed SC’s decision, saying, “India remains steadfast in the pursuit of democracy”. Aaditya Thackeray of Shiv Sena (UBT) said justice and relief to Kejriwal against the “dictatorial regime” in the country was a huge sign of winds of change.
Article Summary: Aam Aadmi Party and INDIA bloc for Lok Sabha elections in Delhi and other states has got a shot in the arm with Arvind Kejriwal set to join it from Saturday. The Delhi chief minister is losing no time in hitting the campaign trail. He will participate in a roadshow in south Delhi on Saturday along with his Punjab counterpart, Bhagwant Mann.

Article Title: 100-km from state capital, villagers seek link to human existence
Article Text: Inside the Cotigao Wildlife Sanctuary , more than 100km from Panaji and some 25km from Canacona town, a road veers off from known human existence and into the wilderness.It is a bumpy ride on a mud road from here, lined with tall forest trees and signboards of the Goa forest department cautioning about leopards and gaurs lurking around. This ride is no forest safari.It is the road to Nadkem, where at least 150 tribals reside.It is the road the children of Nadkem tread by foot to attend school. The hamlet is separated by just a 3-km forest stretch from Karnataka.“During the monsoons, when the water levels in the forest streams rise, the children cannot go to school. None of us can go anywhere,” says Anand Gaonkar, 52, who acts as the de facto village head.Not even an ambulance can get to Nadkem in case of medical emergencies.At this Lok Sabha polls, the villagers have only heard of candidates or parties holding meetings, but no candidate has roughed it out yet to reach them.In the past, candidates like Francisco Sardinha have travelled to Nadkem, but only to seek votes.“They come once and don’t show their faces once elected,” said Anand.There are 137 votes at Nadkem in all, including 59 at Keri, a hamlet worse off, with even no power at the four homes, a one-hour walk uphill from Nadkem.“So many MLAs and MPs have come and gone, but our issues remain. For 20 homes, we have only two toilets, one provided by govt. The nearest hospital is at Chaudi, 25km away. We have no tap water in homes because we were told we would be charged by govt to draw our spring water into the houses,” said another villager, Yeshwant Gaonkar.Their only jobs are as daily wagers.MLA Ramesh Tawadkar, a tribal himself, has promised to construct a road and the villagers remain hopeful.“We had decided to boycott the last zilla panchayat elections. But there are other villages here like Keri and Yeda whose residents decided to vote any way. Later, the mamlatdar and deputy collector urged us to vote too, and the boycott could not achieve its purpose,” said Mahadev Velip.As a result of the boycott probably, the village balwadi was turned into a polling booth and for the first time this Lok Sabha election, Nadkem residents will not have to trek 5-6km through the jungles to cast their vote.The village received an electricity connection in 2012 and streetlights were provided only last Diwali.“For water supply, one common tap has been provided from where the women still have to carry water home every day for the entire family’s requirement. It would make life much easier for us women if the water is supplied to the homes,” said Anand’s wife Amita, who recollects a much more convenient life prior to marriage in her maternal home in Gaondongorim village.Anand’s son has finally managed to complete his graduation, a big feat in the remote village, after his daily-wager father gathered the funds for a rented premises in Canacona.Women due for deliveries too have to be shifted to relatives' homes because Nadkem is no place for emergencies.The village head has now purchased a four-wheeler that acts as the entire hamlet’s emergency service.“How will we leave this village? This is our home. If we could only be provided a road, we would not ask for anything else,” says Anand.
Article Summary: At least 150 tribals live in Nadkem, 100km from Panaji and 25km from Canacona. The hamlet is separated by just a 3-km forest stretch from Karnataka. For 20 homes, we have only two toilets, one provided by govt. The nearest hospital is at Chaudi, 25km away.

Article Title: Little by little, villagers of Vainguinim dig a road to civilization
Article Text: Survival expert Bear Gryll would probably shy away from their everyday lives. The daily routine of the 50-odd residents of Vainguinim is a physical challenge.Sattari, over 50km from Panaji, is considered Goa’s rural taluka. And Vainguinim begins where Sattari nearly ends. It is a mere 5km from the Karnataka border.Only off-roading on a two-wheeler across three streams can take one to this tribal hamlet, inside the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary.Decades of scraping with their own hands have allowed the residents to create this mud road.The state forest department’s recent efforts to even out this path have helped, but there is much more left to be done before these villagers can claim to live a normal life.“Through solar panels on our thatched rooftops, govt provided us with electricity in 2022. But none of the houses have toilets yet. We dug wells on our own to access drinking water. Until 12 years ago, we would use stream water for drinking. With no road, our children must stay with relatives outside the village to study, or they don’t go to school at all,” says Rama Gaonkar.It is not surprising that no Lok Sabha candidate has ever turned up here for campaigning, but that will not stop the villagers from exercising their franchise by walking 5km through the forest to their polling booth at Codal village. “It is our vote, and we have to cast it,” says Laxman Gaonkar.“Road, water, and electricity are what we need. MLA Vishwajit Rane summoned us for a meeting at Satre and has promised to meet our demands. Things will improve gradually, as they have since our childhood,” says Yesso Gaonkar.While the adults of the village live outside Vainguinim for daily-wage jobs, the elderly remain cut off from the world during the monsoon as water in the streams rises.“If someone falls ill, they will have to die with no medical treatment,” says Rama. “If possible, the sick are taken pillion on bikes. Cellphones have been a boon. At least someone can be summoned with a bike. Until 15 years ago, there was no road, and there was no way to get here.”Rama’s son has been fortunate to have earned a priced govt job in the police department, and that has provided hope to others, like Rajendra Gaonkar. They seek daily-wage jobs to afford the rent to live in Valpoi so that their children can complete their graduation.“Those with children have to stay on rent and work for daily wages so that the kids can go to school. There is no way to attend school if we stay in Vainguinim. If you live in the village, betelnut and cashew are the only other sources of income,” says Rajendra, who has two sons.Hope is their best bet.
Article Summary: Vainguinim, over 50km from Panaji, is considered Goa’s rural taluka. It is a mere 5km from the Karnataka border. The elderly remain cut off from the world during the monsoon as water in the streams rises.

Article Title: As taps run dry in arid Aurangabad, candidates go on and on about booze
Article Text: CHHATRAPATI SAMBHAJINAGAR: In the heart of Maharashtra lies Aurangabad , a city grappling with parched throats and dry taps. However, the talk here isn't about quenching thirst but spirits of a different kind. As the political arena heats up, liquor has become the toast of conversations, overshadowing even the most pressing issues - the chronic water scarcity plaguing the region.It began when CM Eknath Shinde's Shiv Sena named Sandipan Bhumare as the candidate for Aurangabad - the Lok Sabha seat retains the old name of the city, now known as Chhatrapati Sambhajinagar. Bhumare's rivals wasted no time in levelling accusations against him, alleging that he owns nine liquor shops in Paithan, a charge he vehemently denies.As the mudslinging intensifies, Bhumare advises his opponents to peruse his poll affidavit, where he claims his wife is the owner of two liquor shops. "The details are clearly outlined in my affidavit, readily available to everyone. I dutifully pay taxes for the establishments," he says.Deputy CM Ajit Pawar, an adversary turned ally now with BJP-led Mahayuti, previously spearheaded the attack against Bhumare when he was in the undivided NCP. However, in the shifting landscape of alliances, where partnerships are as fleeting as shadows at dusk, Ajit's voice has faded into silence, but others carry on the onslaught against Bhumare's alleged liquor empire.The Sena faction under Uddhav Thackeray has been particularly vocal, labelling Bhumare a "liquor baron". Sena (UBT) candidate Chandrakant Khaire emphasised his own track record at a recent rally, saying, "I served as an MP for 20 years, always with a clear priority. While my opponent held the MLA position for five terms, his attention seemed fixed on opening liquor shops. The choice lies with you, the people."Even All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen (AIMIM) chief Asaduddin Owaisi has composed a catchy jingle borrowed from Aziz Nazan's iconic qawwali often heard in dive bars - it goes something like "Jhoom re, Bhumare; jhoom barabar jhoom re."Amid this cacophony, voters lament that the sparring over liquor, rather than the water crisis, is a "mockery of democracy". As the blame game ensues over delayed water projects, voters are disillusioned with the circus.Renuka Beedkar, a homemaker, remarked, "Neither the ruling Mahayuti nor the opposition Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) addresses the water woes in our so-called metropolis. Opting for NOTA seems the only way to express our exasperation."Swapnil Bhoomkar, a resident of Padegaon, said they have to rely on borewells and private tankers. "We shell out a small fortune every week for water. Our predicament surpasses even that people in rural areas face."There's a triangular contest in Aurangabad this cycle. In 2019, Imtiaz Jaleel of AIMIM surprised analysts with a razor-thin victory by 4,492 votes, expanding the party's footprint beyond Telangana.Five years on, he anticipates another multi-cornered battle that may fragment non-minorities votes. However, unlike the previous , AIMIM is without the support of Prakash Ambedkar-led Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi, which has fielded its own nominee, Afsar Khan.Jaleel, however, remains confident in his ability to bridge divides and serve all constituents, irrespective of religion. He places his confidence in his endeavours, particularly in bolstering public health infrastructure in the area. "It wasn't just Muslims, but also Hindus and people from other communities who backed me in the previous elections. I delivered on their expectations and fostered unity instead of discord."Among the six assembly segments in the LS seat, three are held by Shiv Sena and two by BJP, providing an edge to Bhumare, who was selected over Maratha activist Vinod Patil. Says Bhumare, "The nation is experiencing rapid progress under PM Narendra Modi. Once again, the voters of Aurangabad will stand with him, and thus, they will elect me to the Lok Sabha."Meanwhile, for Khaire, a seasoned campaigner, this marks his last stand. With the backing of former corporators and a section of workers, Khaire hopes to reclaim his seat, banking on past achievements and party loyalty. Despite the party split, the Sena (UBT) candidate still garners support from a group of former corporators and a segment of workers.He also relies on the endorsement of the leader of the opposition in the council, Ambadas Danve. Notably, Danve had eyed a Lok Sabha ticket but reluctantly accepted the party's decision. "My defeat in the previous polls was an anomaly. I trust that the people will choose me once more," he says.Yet, the political arena extends beyond the primary contenders. Former Kannad MLA Harshwardhan Jadhav, now an Independent candidate, seeks to disrupt the prevailing order. Additionally, with Prakash Ambedkar's Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi fielding Afsar Khan, the stage is primed for an ideological showdown.As the campaign intensifies, Ambedkar's call for change resonates with many disenchanted voters. Amid the rhetoric and promises, one undeniable reality persists: water, not liquor, is the lifeblood of Aurangabad. As Monday's poll approaches, the spotlight intensifies on Aurangabad, a city torn between thirst for change and intoxicating allure of status quo.
Article Summary: Sandipan Bhumare is the Shiv Sena's candidate for Aurangabad Lok Sabha seat. His rivals allege that he owns nine liquor shops in Paithan, a charge he denies. AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi has composed a catchy jingle borrowed from Aziz Nazan's iconic qawwali.

Article Title: Low turnout, not BJP, Owaisi’s biggest worry
Article Text:
Most parties leave

BJP main target this time

Falling turnout a concern

BJP very much in this race

HYDERABAD: Hyderabad Lok Sabha seat has been an Owaisi family bastion since 1984, and a fifth win here would put Asaduddin Owaisi ahead of his father, Sultan Salahuddin Owaisi, who represented it for 20 years until 2004.Asad has won every election here with a huge margin, representing AIMIM , the party his father joined after winning his first seat as an Independent.He’s also become the Muslim community’s most visible and vocal face in his 20 years as MP. But the triangular contest with BJP and Congress might not be so easy this time. Although 60% of Hyderabad constituency is Muslim, and Asad is the front-runner, he’s up against BJP’s K Madhavi Latha, who revels in controversy, and Congress’s Mohammad Waliullah Sameer, who might split Asad’s Muslim votes .Him Alone Political observers say AIMIM keeps winning Hyderabad because it projects itself as the voice of weaker sections, especially Muslims, in 45 Telangana assembly seats where they make up 8-20% of the population.Other parties, which need these Muslim votes, go easy in Hyderabad to keep AIMIM on their side. In fact, local Congress leaders complain cosying up to AIMIM since the days of undivided Andhra has almost finished their party in the old city of Hyderabad, and their leaders and cadres are not encouraged to put up a strong contest.It’s not that Congress and Telugu Desam Party, which governed undivided Andhra at different times, didn’t try to challenge AIMIM (Congress last won the seat in 1980), but they soon realised it was better to keep the party on their side by leaving 7-8 assembly segments and one Lok Sabha constituency for it. And AIMIM mostly confined itself to the old city, barring a few occasions when the party in office rubbed it the wrong way. For example, AIMIM-Congress ties turned sour after the events that unfolded from Nov 2012 to Jan 2013. When five AIMIM MLAs were placed in preventive custody over the Charminar-Bhagyalakshmi temple issue, and Asad’s younger brother Akbaruddin Owaisi was arrested for an alleged hate speech, AIMIM sided with K Chandrasekhar Rao-led Bharat Rashtra Samithi (then TRS). This bonhomie lasted until BRS lost the 2023 assembly elections.This time, the talk is that Asad and Akbar are extending seat-wise support to the party — BRS or Congress — that’s in a position to defeat BJP. In fact, Asad has declared that their main objective is to defeat BJP. Outside Telangana, however, AIMIM candidates will take on Congress and other parties in some seats. The AIMIM-Congress patch-up started after Congress got only four seats over the half-way mark in Telangana. State Congress president and now chief minister A Revanth Reddy extended an olive branch to AIMIM by laying the foundation stone for metro rail works in old Hyderabad and promising overall development. Owaisi responded by assuring that his seven MLAs would back Congress if it lost majority.Then, Akbar and Revanth hit it off in London in Jan while visiting the Thames river project, in the backdrop of the CM’s plan to revive Musi river that flows through Hyderabad. The proposed Musi riverfront development would cost Rs 50,000 crore.He has the alignments worked out, but Asad still needs to worry about voter fatigue and his seat’s falling turnout. In 1999, when his father last contested, 69.2% of the electorate voted, but in 2019 the number plummeted to 44.8%, despite AIMIM cadres pleading with people to go out and vote. Nobody knows for sure why Hy derabadis have become ballot-shy. Experts say it might be that Muslims expect Asad to win, whether they vote or not. Or they may be disheartened, feeling their vote makes no difference nationally.So, Asad has been campaigning relentlessly through the streets of the old city, riding his Triumph Bonneville bike sometimes, and walking through the narrow lanes on others. He tells people to not stay home on voting day, for their safety.While it has never won Hyderabad, BJP does have a big presence here. Its candidates have finished second in four out of five Lok Sabha elections to this seat, with decent vote shares, while Congress has always finished third or fourth. BJP’s Bhagwant Rao got 32.1% of the votes polled in 2014, and 26.8% in 2019. Experts say this is because sharp rhetoric from AIMIM and BJP leaders has deeply divided the Hyderabad electorate. The seat’s Goshamahal assembly segment is a bastion of T Raha Singh, BJP’s most aggressive Hindutva face in the city. The party once suspended him along with Nupur Sharma for comments on Prophet Mohammed. On the other side, Akbar has a police case against him for threatening an inspector who told him campaign time was over.
Article Summary: Asad has won every election here with a huge margin, representing AIMIM. But the triangular contest with BJP and Congress might not be so easy this time. 60% of Hyderabad constituency is Muslim, and Asad is the front-runner.

Article Title: Andhra Pradesh high court pulls up Election Commission over cash benefit transfer
Article Text: VIJAYAWADA: The Andhra Pradesh high court on Friday pulled up the Election Commission of India (ECI) for seeking clarification from the AP state govt over disbursal of amount under various welfare schemes even after its directions. The high court questioned lack of uniformity in ECI orders pertaining to welfare schemes in different states. However, the high court did not grant any relief to the state govt and posted the matter for further hearing after summer vacation.The state govt and a few beneficiaries of welfare schemes moved the high court challenging the directions issued by the ECI refraining the govt from depositing money into the accounts of beneficiaries of various schemes.After a day-long hearing over the petitions, the high court had on Thursday kept the directions of ECI in abeyance for one day till May 10. The high court, however, directed the state govt not to deposit any money from May 11 till May 13.The high court had further directed the state govt not to publicise in any form about depositing money into the accounts of beneficiaries. Challenging the single judge orders, Navataram Party moved an appeal petition on Friday and pressed for urgent hearing by way of lunch motion.Arguing on behalf of the petitioner, senior counsels NS Nadkarni and Meenakshi Arora said that the single judge orders are unusual. While ordering the state govt not to deposit money from May 11 till May 13, the single judge facilitated the govt to deposit the amounts on May 10 which is nothing but vitiating the level playing field. They have said that the orders of a single judge are in favour of the ruling party and against the interest of opposition parties contesting the election. Allowing the govt to deposit Rs 14000 crore of money, two days before the polling would give undue advantage to the ruling dispensation, they have said.Arguing on behalf of the state govt, advocate general S Sriram said that the govt has sought no objection certificate (NOC) from ECI after the single judge orders. Without giving the NOC, the ECI has raised further clarifications. The chief secretary has submitted an explanation to the queries raised by the ECI. However, as the NOC is not granted by the ECI, the govt could not deposit the money into the accounts of beneficiaries, he said.Sriram further said that the ECI has violated the orders of the single judge by not giving NOC. He said that in 2019, the ECI allowed the then govt to give post-dated cheques to the beneficiaries but this time took a contrarian view on the same issue. He said that an in-depth hearing is required on the contrarian decisions taken by the ECI and requested to keep the appeal petitions open.Arguing on behalf of the ECI, senior counsel Avinash Desai said that the single judge neither said to deposit money into the accounts of beneficiaries nor mentioned any reasons for giving such orders. He said that the ECI has clarified that the schemes can be implemented after the polling date. The ECI has sought additional clarifications from the govt for issuing of NOC.The high court bench headed by Chief Justice Dheeraj Singh Thakur and Justice R Raghunandan Rao asked ECI as to why it has chosen to sit on single judge orders instead of filing an appeal if it has any apprehensions over the same. The bench asked as to why the ECI sought clarifications from govt even after the orders of the high court. The bench asked whether the ECI thinks that it is above the high court.However, the bench observed that no further orders need to be passed as the govt has in any case not disbursed the amount for want of clearance from the ECI and in the disbursal of amount will not take place on Friday. As the single judge orders will come into force from Saturday refraining the govt from depositing the amounts till May 13, on May 14 the amount may be disbursed as submitted by the ECI, said the high court and posted the matters for further hearing on September 2.
Article Summary: The high court questioned lack of uniformity in ECI orders pertaining to welfare schemes in different states. The state govt and a few beneficiaries of welfare schemes moved the high court challenging the directions issued by the ECI refraining the govt from depositing money into the accounts of beneficiaries of various schemes. The high court did not grant any relief and posted the matter for further hearing after summer vacation.

Article Title: Pakistan SC suspends Peshawar HC order denying reserved seats to Imran-backed party
Article Text: ISLAMABAD: Pakistan’s Supreme Court suspended on Monday a high court verdict that a political party aligned with candidates backed by incarcerated former prime minister Imran Khan was not eligible for reserved seats for women and minorities in the national and provincial legislatures.Since the Khan-led Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) was barred by the top court from contesting the Feb 8 elections under its traditional electoral symbol of a cricket bat on technical grounds, the party had subsequently struck an alliance with another party, Sunni Ittehad Council (SIC), in an attempt to secure reserved seats in parliament.Under Pakistan’s election rules, political parties are allotted reserved seats — (there are 60 for women and 10 for minorities in the National Assembly) — in proportion to the number of parliamentary seats they win in the election. This completes the NA’s total strength of 336 seats.In March, the Election Commission of Pakistan (ECP) had ruled that SIC was not eligible for reserved seats and decided to distribute the seats among other parliamentary parties, with the ruling Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) and the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) becoming major beneficiaries. The verdict was rejected by PTI as unconstitutional and the alliance had filed a plea against the electoral watchdog’s decision in the Peshawar HC, but it rejected the appeal.In response, SIC moved the Supreme Court last month urging it to allot the party the reserved seats in the national and provincial assemblies and set aside the Peshawar HC ruling.Accepting SIC’s appeal for a hearing, the apex court clarified that the Peshawar HC order upholding ECP’s decision was suspended to the extent of the remaining reserved seats distributed among other parties.After losing the extra reserved seats, PM Shehbaz Sharif’s coalition government had lost its two-thirds majority in the National Assembly.
Article Summary: Pakistan’s Supreme Court suspended on Monday a high court verdict that a political party was not eligible for reserved seats for women and minorities. Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf was barred by the top court from contesting the Feb 8 elections under its traditional electoral symbol of a cricket bat. The party subsequently struck an alliance with another party, Sunni Ittehad Council (SIC), in an attempt to secure reserved seats.

Article Title: Sri Lanka to hold prez election from Sept 17 to Oct 16
Article Text: COLOMBO: Sri Lanka will hold presidential election between Sept 17 and Oct 16, the election commission said Thursday.Prez Ranil Wickremesinghe , whose term ends in Nov, is likely to seek a mandate for the economic reforms he is carrying out in exchange for a $3 billion IMF bailout loan . He was elected by lawmakers in 2022 after Gotabaya Rajapaksa quit following weeks of protests.Wickremesinghe, 75, will represent several parties as a national candidate under a new symbol, his aide said last month. He has led UNP since 1994. He has served as PM on five occasions.Wickremesinghe may face challenge from his justice minister Wijeyadasa Rajapakshe . Former prez Maithripala Sirisena, the chairman of Sri Lanka Freedom Party , has said that Rajapakshe, 65, would be his party's candidate.
Article Summary: Prez Ranil Wickremesinghe is likely to seek a mandate for the economic reforms he is carrying out in exchange for a $3 billion IMF bailout loan. He was elected by lawmakers in 2022 after Gotabaya Rajapaksa quit following weeks of protests.

Article Title: CM A Revanth Reddy: BJP, MIM out to flare up religious tension to win polls
Article Text: HYDERABAD: Chief minister A Revanth Reddy on Friday said BJP and AIMIM were trying to win Hyderabad Lok Sabha seat by creating a rift between Hindus and Muslims . He also said neither Prime Minister Narendra Modi nor Asaduddin Owaisi did anything to remove poverty and change the lives of the people in the Old City.Addressing a street-corner meeting in Goshamahal , he said the BJP wants to create communal tension and take away investments from Telangana to Gujarat."The people of this historic city have to decide whether they want communal tensions and curfews, which will rob them of their business and push Greater Hyderabad backwards," he said."We do not want law and order situations to go out of control. But the BJP and AIMIM are trying to flare up religious emotions," he said."Congress is in power in the state and can develop the Old City, Musi riverfront project, complete Metro rail and other projects," Revanth said while campaigning for party candidate Mohammed Waliullah Sameer. The CM spoke mostly in Hindi.He said Muslims, Marwadis, Gujaratis and people of other communities have been living in this part of the city. "Why did not the BJP govt, which was in power for 10 years at the Centre, bring metro rail to the Old City or give funds for Musi riverfront project," he sought to ask.
Article Summary: Chief minister A Revanth Reddy said BJP and AIMIM were trying to win Hyderabad Lok Sabha seat by creating a rift between Hindus and Muslims. He said neither Prime Minister Narendra Modi nor Asaduddin Owaisi did anything to remove poverty and change the lives of the people in the Old City.
